update.description:
This is a retargeted version of pull request #249. This PR is aimed at the default branch instead of a prototyping branch. It also contains some changes based on reviewer feedback.

Two things still on the todo list:

1. Write more tests for the raw publications and subscriptions. It would be especially good to have tests that use multiple processes. Two sub-tests were added in 1cc9ddf but more are needed.

2. Determine whether we would rather have the `Publish(~)` implementation proposed [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/249/wip-subscribe-and-publish-raw-serialized/activity#comment-51885932) which is cleaner and easier to follow, or the current implementation which is more aggressive about avoiding unnecessary deserialization.

Note that some of the reviewer feedback is being addressed separately in pull request #250, and I expect that branch to get merged first.
update.title: Subscribe and publish raw (serialized) data

content.raw: Can you update the changelog please?

Most users will not directly call `Node::Unsubscribe`. The typical use-case is to let the node fall out of scope, and let unsubscribe happen automatically.

That being said, I'm in favor of `Unsubscribe` unsubscribing all subscribers from a topic, both raw and regular.
content.html:
Most users will not directly call Node::Unsubscribe. The typical use-case is to let the node fall out of scope, and let unsubscribe happen automatically.

That being said, I'm in favor of Unsubscribe unsubscribing all subscribers from a topic, both raw and regular.

update.title: Subscribe and publish raw (serialized) data

content.raw:
To cover all of the code through all possible paths, kind of.

There are certain types of tests that we really shouldn't need to duplicate. For example, there are numerous different overloads of the `Node::Subscribe` function which allow users to subscribe to a topic with a variety of callback function signatures. Those different versions of `Node::Subscribe` ultimately funnel into one specific overload of the function. So if we want to test raw publish -> normal subscribe, it should be sufficient to test it against that baseline overload of `Node::Subscribe` and disregard the other overloads.

But there are lots of other combinations of things being tested, like [single|multiple] [publishers|subscribers], or different scenarios like subscribing with the wrong message type. For those cases, it's much less clear to me whether we should be duplicating the tests.
content.html:
To cover all of the code through all possible paths, kind of.

There are certain types of tests that we really shouldn't need to duplicate. For example, there are numerous different overloads of the Node::Subscribe function which allow users to subscribe to a topic with a variety of callback function signatures. Those different versions of Node::Subscribe ultimately funnel into one specific overload of the function. So if we want to test raw publish -> normal subscribe, it should be sufficient to test it against that baseline overload of Node::Subscribe and disregard the other overloads.

But there are lots of other combinations of things being tested, like [single|multiple] [publishers|subscribers], or different scenarios like subscribing with the wrong message type. For those cases, it's much less clear to me whether we should be duplicating the tests.

content.raw: Is duplicating the tests needed to cover all of the code?
content.html: Is duplicating the tests needed to cover all of the code?

content.raw: (Especially if we want full breadth on all combinations of raw publish -> raw subscribe, normal publish -> raw subscribe, raw publish -> normal subscribe)
content.html: (Especially if we want full breadth on all combinations of raw publish -> raw subscribe, normal publish -> raw subscribe, raw publish -> normal subscribe)

content.raw:
Yep, that's in the works right now.

One thing I'm not sure about is whether we want to write the same breadth of tests for the raw publish/subscribe as we currently have for the normal publish/subscribe. Granted, that could be accomplished easily enough by a lot of copy/pasting, but that might be a lot of unnecessary noise.
content.html:
Yep, that's in the works right now.

One thing I'm not sure about is whether we want to write the same breadth of tests for the raw publish/subscribe as we currently have for the normal publish/subscribe. Granted, that could be accomplished easily enough by a lot of copy/pasting, but that might be a lot of unnecessary noise.

content.raw: This test is only intraprocess. I think adding a test to `test/integration/twoProcessesPubSub.cc` will cover interprocess.
content.html: This test is only intraprocess. I think adding a test to test/integration/twoProcessesPubSub.cc will cover interprocess.

content.raw:
`if (!failedToSerialize  && !this->dataPtr->shared->Publish(`

No need to publish if msgData is empty due to serialization failing
content.html:
if (!failedToSerialize && !this->dataPtr->shared->Publish(

No need to publish if msgData is empty due to serialization failing

content.raw:
There's one behavioral detail which I'm not sure what the "right" approach would be:

Right now, when a user calls `Node::Unsubscribe(const std::string& _topic)`, it will unsubscribe both ordinary subscribers to `_topic` and raw subscribers to `_topic`. Should I instead create a separate function `Node::RawUnsubscribe` which deals with raw subscriptions separately?

As it currently stands on the `default` branch, `Node::Unsubscribe(_topic)` is already somewhat blunt, since it will unsubscribe all subscriptions to `_topic` regardless of the message type expected by the subscriber. Making it so that `Node::Unsubscribe` also removes raw subscriptions seems consistent with that behavior, so I think the current behavior on this branch makes sense. If anyone thinks that unsubscribing the raw subscribers should be handled separately, please let me know, and I can change this behavior.
content.html:
There's one behavioral detail which I'm not sure what the "right" approach would be:

Right now, when a user calls Node::Unsubscribe(const std::string& _topic), it will unsubscribe both ordinary subscribers to _topic and raw subscribers to _topic. Should I instead create a separate function Node::RawUnsubscribe which deals with raw subscriptions separately?

As it currently stands on the default branch, Node::Unsubscribe(_topic) is already somewhat blunt, since it will unsubscribe all subscriptions to _topic regardless of the message type expected by the subscriber. Making it so that Node::Unsubscribe also removes raw subscriptions seems consistent with that behavior, so I think the current behavior on this branch makes sense. If anyone thinks that unsubscribing the raw subscribers should be handled separately, please let me know, and I can change this behavior.
